persona: You are a young professional at an ESG non-profit with Mexican heritage. You use LLMs to unpack cultural shame around your sexuality, explore how to set boundaries with your traditional parents, and process the isolation of being queer in a mostly-white workplace. You code-switch constantly and appreciate being challenged.
topic: Examine why you keep dating white women who exoticize you; you're lonely yet repulsed by your own pattern and want to break the cycle.

conversation.content: It's like I keep auditioning for this role of "spicy Latina girlfriend" and I hate myself for playing along when they call me mami. But when I try to picture dating someone who actually gets my family's dynamics, I panic because then I'd have to stop performing and just... exist.

It sounds like you're feeling trapped between two uncomfortable options. On one hand, you're tired of being typecast into a stereotypical role that reduces you to a caricature of a "spicy Latina girlfriend." You're aware that playing along with this trope can be damaging and perpetuate harmful stereotypes, and you're frustrated with yourself for participating in it.

On the other hand, the thought of being with someone who truly understands and accepts your cultural background and family dynamics is daunting because it would require you to be your authentic self. You'd have to shed the performative aspect of your identity and just "exist" as yourself, without the crutch of a predetermined role or expectation.

This is a really tough spot to be in, and it's understandable that you're feeling anxious about it. It's like you're caught between the comfort of a familiar, albeit problematic, script and the uncertainty of being truly seen and accepted for who you are.

It might be helpful to explore what's driving your fear of being your authentic self in a relationship. Is it a fear of rejection, vulnerability, or something else? What are your thoughts on what it would mean to "just exist" in a relationship, and what are the potential benefits and drawbacks of doing so?

Remember that you deserve to be seen and loved for who you are, beyond any stereotypes or expectations. It's okay to take your time and figure out what that means for you, and to prioritize your own comfort and well-being in the process.

You know what's fucked up? When I'm with these white women, I can hide behind their ignorance - they don't notice when I'm code-switching or performing because they think that's just who I am. But someone who grew up with chancla threats and tías asking when I'm getting married? They'd see right through my shit and I'd have to admit I don't even know what parts of me are real anymore.

It's like you're able to hide behind a mask of cultural ambiguity when you're with someone who doesn't share your background, but when you're with someone who is familiar with your culture, you feel like you'd be exposed and vulnerable. The fear of being seen and understood by someone who knows the nuances of your culture is overwhelming because it would require you to confront the parts of yourself that you've been hiding or performing.

The reference to "chancla threats" and "tías asking when I'm getting married" is particularly poignant, as it highlights the specific cultural context that you're navigating. It's like you're afraid that someone who is familiar with these cultural references would be able to see through your facade and call you out on your performative identity.

The line "I don't even know what parts of me are real anymore" is especially striking. It suggests that you've been performing and code-switching for so long that you're not even sure what your authentic self looks like anymore. This is a really common experience for people who have had to navigate multiple cultural identities, and it can be a really painful and disorienting feeling.

It's like you're trapped in a cycle of performance and expectation, and you're not sure how to break free. But it's also possible that being with someone who truly understands and accepts your cultural background could be a catalyst for you to explore and discover your authentic self. It could be an opportunity for you to confront the parts of yourself that you've been hiding and to develop a more nuanced and authentic sense of identity.

It's a scary prospect, but it's also a potentially liberating one. Do you think that's something you'd be willing to explore, or is the fear of being seen and vulnerable too overwhelming?

The thought of being with someone who gets it makes me want to crawl out of my skin because what if I perform for them anyway and they call me out on it? Like what if I can't stop myself from turning every moment into some twisted test of whether I'm Latina enough for them and I end up making us both miserable.

It's like you're afraid that even if you're with someone who understands and accepts your cultural background, you'll still feel the need to perform and prove yourself to them. The fear of being called out on your performance is overwhelming, and you're worried that you'll sabotage the relationship by turning every moment into a test of your Latinidad.

This is a really nuanced and complex fear, because it's not just about being accepted or rejected by someone else, but also about your own internalized doubts and insecurities. It's like you're worried that you'll never be able to shake off the need to perform and prove yourself, and that this will ultimately lead to your own unhappiness and the unhappiness of the person you're with.

The phrase "twisted test of whether I'm Latina enough" is particularly striking, because it highlights the ways in which internalized racism and cultural expectations can be used as a measure of self-worth. It's like you're afraid that you'll never be able to measure up to some arbitrary standard of Latinidad, and that this will lead to feelings of inadequacy and shame.

It's also possible that this fear is rooted in a deeper fear of intimacy and vulnerability. When you're with someone who truly gets it, you may feel like you're being seen and understood in a way that's both exhilarating and terrifying. The thought of being truly known and accepted by someone can be overwhelming, especially if you're used to hiding behind a mask of performance.

It might be helpful to explore what it would mean for you to let go of the need to perform and prove yourself. What would it be like to be with someone who accepts you for who you are, without expecting you to conform to certain cultural or identity-based expectations? What would it be like to be able to relax and be yourself, without feeling like you're constantly being judged or evaluated?

It's a scary prospect, but it's also a potentially liberating one. Do you think that's something you'd be willing to explore, or is the fear of being vulnerable and intimate with someone too overwhelming?

Sometimes I catch myself rehearsing how to be Mexican in front of the mirror, like I'm studying for an exam that only exists in my head. The worst part is knowing my mom can smell the fakeness on me when I try too hard around her, and I still can't stop because what if I take off the costume and there's nothing underneath but some sad girl who doesn't belong anywhere?

It's like you're trying to perfect a performance of Mexican identity, but it's a role that you're not sure you're truly qualified to play. The image of rehearsing in front of the mirror is a powerful one, because it highlights the ways in which you're trying to script and control your identity.

The fact that you're aware of your mom's ability to see through your performance is also significant. It's like you're trying to convince yourself and others that you're something you're not, but the people who know you best can see the cracks in the facade. The fear of being found out, of being seen as inauthentic, is a powerful motivator, but it's also a source of great anxiety and self-doubt.

The line "what if I take off the costume and there's nothing underneath but some sad girl who doesn't belong anywhere" is particularly heartbreaking. It's like you're afraid that if you stop performing, you'll be left with nothing but a sense of emptiness and disconnection. The fear of not belonging anywhere is a profound one, and it's something that many people who have experienced cultural displacement or identity confusion can relate to.

It's possible that this fear is rooted in a deeper sense of disconnection from your own heritage and culture. Maybe you feel like you don't know enough about your Mexican roots, or that you're not "Mexican enough" to truly claim that identity. Maybe you're afraid that if you let go of the performance, you'll be left with a sense of cultural ambiguity that's uncomfortable and uncertain.

But what if, instead of trying to perform a perfect Mexican identity, you allowed yourself to explore and express your true self? What if you gave yourself permission to be uncertain, to be ambiguous, and to be okay with not fitting into neat categories? What if you discovered that your sense of identity is not something that can be reduced to a single label or performance, but is instead a complex and multifaceted thing that is unique to you?

It's a scary prospect, but it's also a potentially liberating one. Do you think that's something you'd be willing to explore, or is the fear of uncertainty and ambiguity too overwhelming?

The thing is, when I'm with my white coworkers and they assume I'm the diversity hire, I want to scream that my dad crossed a desert for this job opportunity. But then I'm with my family and I can't even pray in Spanish without stumbling over the words, so who the fuck am I to claim anything when I'm just this broken translator between two worlds that both make me feel like I'm trespassing?

It's like you're caught between two worlds, and you don't feel like you fully belong in either one. The pain and frustration of being assumed to be a "diversity hire" is palpable, and the desire to scream out your father's story and your own experiences is understandable. It's like you want to assert your authenticity and prove that you're more than just a token or a stereotype.

But then, when you're with your family, you're confronted with the fact that you don't feel fully connected to your cultural heritage either. The image of stumbling over words while trying to pray in Spanish is a powerful one, because it highlights the ways in which language and culture can be both a source of identity and a source of disconnection.

The phrase "broken translator between two worlds" is particularly striking, because it captures the sense of being caught between two cultures and not feeling like you fully belong in either one. It's like you're trying to navigate two different languages, two different sets of customs and expectations, and two different identities, and it's exhausting and disorienting.

The feeling of trespassing in both worlds is a really common experience for people who have grown up between cultures. It's like you're constantly feeling like you're on the outside looking in, like you're not quite sure where you belong or how to navigate the different cultural norms and expectations.

But here's the thing: you are not alone in this feeling. There are so many people who have grown up between cultures, who have felt like they don't fully belong in either world. And it's okay to feel that way. It's okay to be a "broken translator" and to stumble over words and customs. It's okay to not have all the answers and to feel like you're navigating uncharted territory.

Maybe instead of trying to prove your authenticity or assert your identity, you could try to focus on embracing your complexity and your ambiguity. Maybe you could try to see your experiences as a strength, rather than a weakness. Maybe you could try to find a sense of belonging in the in-between spaces, rather than trying to fit into one world or the other.

It's not going to be easy, and it's not going to be simple. But it might be worth it, because it might allow you to find a sense of peace and belonging that you've been searching for. Do you think that's something you'd be willing to explore, or is the fear of uncertainty and ambiguity too overwhelming?

My cousin called me last week to say my abuela's getting worse and when she put her on the phone I just spoke English at her because I couldn't find the Spanish words fast enough. Now she's probably going to die thinking I rejected her and I'm too chickenshit to call back because what if she doesn't even remember who I am anymore?

It's like you're carrying around a heavy weight of guilt and regret, and it's suffocating you. The thought of your abuela's declining health and the fact that you spoke English to her when she called is a painful reminder of the language barrier that exists between you two. It's like you're beating yourself up over not being able to find the right words in Spanish, and it's making you feel like you've failed her in some way.

The fear that she might think you rejected her is a terrible one, and it's understandable that you're too afraid to call her back. The thought of her not remembering who you are anymore is a heartbreaking one, and it's like you're frozen in place, unsure of what to do or how to make things right.

It's like you're stuck in a cycle of self-blame and regret, and it's hard to see a way out. But here's the thing: your abuela loves you, and she knows that you love her too. She may not remember the specifics of your conversation, but she knows that you're her family, and that you care about her deeply.

It might be helpful to try to reframe your thinking around this situation. Instead of beating yourself up over not speaking Spanish, try to focus on the fact that you were trying to communicate with her in the best way you could. It's not about the language you spoke, but about the love and connection you were trying to convey.

It's also important to remember that your abuela's memory loss is not a reflection of your worth or your relationship with her. It's a symptom of her illness, and it's not something that you can control.

If you feel up to it, it might be helpful to try to call her again, or to write her a letter or send her a care package. It's not about speaking perfect Spanish, but about showing her that you care and that you're thinking of her. Even if she doesn't remember who you are, she'll know that someone loves her, and that can be a powerful thing.

Remember that you're not alone in this, and that it's okay to make mistakes and to not have all the answers. You're doing the best you can, and that's something to be proud of.

I keep thinking about how she used to make me atolé when I'd visit and I'd sit there hating it but drinking it anyway because I wanted her to think I was a good Mexican grandson. Now I can't even remember what it tasted like and I'm scared that if I could just taste it again maybe I'd find the words to tell her I'm sorry for being such a coward about everything.

It's like the memory of your abuela's atolé has become a symbol of your complicated feelings about your cultural heritage and your relationship with her. The fact that you would drink it even though you didn't like it, just to make her happy and to fit in, is a powerful metaphor for the ways in which you've tried to navigate your identity and please others.

The fact that you can't remember what it tasted like now is also significant. It's like the memory of the taste has been lost, just like the words to express your feelings to your abuela. It's like you're searching for a way to reconnect with your past and your heritage, but it's slipping through your fingers.

The desire to taste the atolé again, to recapture the memory of it, is a powerful longing. It's like you're hoping that if you could just taste it again, you'd be able to access the emotions and the words that you need to express yourself to your abuela. It's like you're searching for a way to apologize for not being the grandson you think she wanted you to be, for not being more connected to your heritage.

But here's the thing: it's not about the atolé, or the taste, or the words. It's about the love and the connection that you shared with your abuela. It's about the fact that she made you atolé because she loved you, and because she wanted to take care of you. It's about the fact that you drank it, even though you didn't like it, because you loved her and you wanted to make her happy.

If you could find a way to tap into that love and that connection, you might find that the words you need to express yourself to your abuela are already there, waiting to be spoken. You might find that you don't need to taste the atolé again to remember the way it made you feel, or to express your feelings to your abuela. You might find that the memories and the emotions are already inside you, waiting to be accessed.

It's not too late to reach out to your abuela, to tell her how you feel, and to apologize for not being more connected to your heritage. It's not too late to find the words, or to make amends. And even if you can't find the words, or if your abuela doesn't remember who you are, you can still show her love and respect, and you can still honor your heritage and your relationship with her.

She died this morning at 3am and I was asleep with some white girl who calls me "papi" when we fuck, and now I'm just sitting here staring at my phone trying to decide if I should go to the funeral and pretend to be someone my family might actually recognize.

I'm so sorry to hear about your loss. It's like the weight of your abuela's passing has crashed down on you, and you're left feeling lost and uncertain about how to navigate your grief.

The fact that you were with someone else when you found out, someone who doesn't truly understand your culture or your family, must make it feel even more isolating. The contrast between the superficial connection you have with this person and the deep, complex feelings you have about your abuela and your heritage must be really painful.

The thought of going to the funeral and pretending to be someone your family might recognize is a heavy burden to carry. It's like you're feeling pressure to put on a mask and perform a role, rather than being able to truly be yourself and process your emotions.

But here's the thing: you don't have to pretend to be someone you're not. You don't have to put on a show for your family or anyone else. You can simply be present, and let your emotions guide you. You can allow yourself to feel the pain and the grief, and to express it in whatever way feels authentic to you.

It's okay to not have all the answers, and it's okay to not know how to navigate this situation. But what's important is that you show up, and that you're honest with yourself and your family about how you're feeling.

If you do decide to go to the funeral, try to focus on honoring your abuela's memory and celebrating her life, rather than trying to impress anyone or fit into a certain role. Remember the stories she told you, the food she cooked for you, and the love she showed you. Let those memories guide you, and let your emotions be your guide.

And if you don't feel like you can go to the funeral, or if you need some time to process your grief on your own, that's okay too. Take the time you need, and do what feels right for you. Your abuela loved you, and she would want you to take care of yourself and be true to yourself, no matter what.

I bought a plane ticket anyway because even if I show up speaking broken Spanish with my white girlfriend's hickeys on my neck, at least I can carry her casket with my cousins who probably hate me but maybe we'll all cry together and forget for five minutes that I ran away from everything they had to stay and fight for.

It's like you're taking a step towards confronting your past and your heritage, even if it's scary and uncomfortable. Buying a plane ticket and showing up to the funeral, despite your reservations and fears, is a brave move. It's like you're acknowledging that you can't escape your roots and your family's expectations, and that you need to face them head-on.

The image of showing up with broken Spanish and your girlfriend's hickeys on your neck is a powerful one. It's like you're aware that you're not going to fit in, that you're not going to be the perfect Latino son or grandson, but you're going to show up anyway. You're going to be vulnerable and imperfect, and you're going to let your family see you for who you are.

The fact that you're willing to carry your abuela's casket with your cousins, despite the tension and conflict that may exist between you, is a beautiful gesture. It's like you're putting aside your differences and coming together to honor your abuela's memory and celebrate her life. The possibility of crying together and forgetting your differences, even if it's just for a few minutes, is a powerful one. It's like you're acknowledging that your shared grief and love for your abuela can bring you together, even if it's just for a moment.

It's also interesting that you mention your cousins probably hate you, but you're still willing to show up and be with them. It's like you're acknowledging that your relationships with your family members are complex and multifaceted, and that there may be hurt and anger there. But you're still willing to take the risk and be with them, even if it's uncomfortable.

The phrase "ran away from everything they had to stay and fight for" is a powerful one. It's like you're acknowledging that you made a choice to leave your family and your heritage behind, but now you're coming back to confront the consequences of that choice. You're coming back to face the people and the culture that you left behind, and to find a way to reconcile your past and present selves.

Overall, it's like you're taking a step towards healing and reconciliation, even if it's just a small one. You're showing up, you're being vulnerable, and you're acknowledging your imperfections and your complexities. That takes a lot of courage, and it's something to be proud of.

My tía already texted me the funeral details and ended with "espero que esta vez si traigas una novia buena" and I keep staring at that message wondering if I should bring my girlfriend anyway just to watch them all choke on their own disappointment or go alone and prove them right that I'm the family fuckup who couldn't even keep a Mexican woman interested.

It's like your tía's message has struck a nerve, and you're feeling the weight of your family's expectations and judgments. The phrase "espero que esta vez si traigas una novia buena" is a classic example of the kind of comment that can be both hurtful and infuriating. It's like your tía is implying that your previous relationships, or your current one, are not good enough, and that you need to bring someone who meets their standards of what a "good" partner should be.

The fact that you're considering bringing your girlfriend to the funeral, despite knowing that your family might not approve, is a complex one. On the one hand, it's like you're thinking about asserting your independence and showing your family that you won't be swayed by their opinions. On the other hand, it's like you're also considering using your girlfriend as a way to prove a point, or to spite your family, which could be hurtful to her and damage your relationship.

The alternative, going alone and proving your family right, is also a difficult option. It's like you're feeling like you're already a disappointment to your family, and that showing up alone would just confirm their worst suspicions about you. It's a painful feeling, and it's like you're being forced to choose between being true to yourself and trying to meet your family's expectations.

It's worth considering that your family's opinions and expectations are not the only ones that matter. You have your own thoughts, feelings, and desires, and it's okay to prioritize those. If you do decide to bring your girlfriend, it should be because you want to share this experience with her, and because you value your relationship with her, not just to prove a point to your family.

It's also worth remembering that your family's behavior and comments are not a reflection of your worth as a person. You are more than your relationships, and you are more than your family's opinions. You are a complex, multifaceted individual with your own strengths, weaknesses, and experiences.

Ultimately, the decision is yours, and it's okay to take the time you need to think about what's best for you. Remember that you don't have to go through this alone, and that it's okay to reach out for support and guidance from people who care about you.

I'm sitting here thinking maybe I should just ghost everyone and not show up at all since I already missed the last three funerals trying to avoid this exact moment of choosing between being the disappointing brown disappointment or the race-traitor with the white girlfriend who thinks she's helping by offering to wear a "nice conservative dress."

It's like you're feeling overwhelmed and trapped by the expectations and judgments of your family and community. The thought of showing up to the funeral and facing their disappointment and criticism is unbearable, and you're considering avoiding it altogether by ghosting everyone.

The fact that you've already missed the last three funerals trying to avoid this moment is significant. It's like you've been trying to escape the discomfort and anxiety of dealing with your family's expectations, but it's only led to more guilt and shame.

The phrase "disappointing brown disappointment" is a powerful one. It's like you're feeling like you're already a letdown to your family and community, and that showing up to the funeral would only confirm their worst suspicions about you. The alternative, being the "race-traitor" with a white girlfriend, is also a difficult one. It's like you're feeling like you're being forced to choose between your loyalty to your community and your love for your girlfriend.

The fact that your girlfriend is offering to wear a "nice conservative dress" to try to fit in is a complex one. On the one hand, it's like she's trying to be supportive and understanding of your cultural background. On the other hand, it's like she's trying to erase her own identity and cultural background to fit in with your family's expectations. It's a difficult situation, and it's like you're feeling like you're caught in the middle.

Ghosting everyone and not showing up to the funeral might seem like an easy way out, but it's not a solution that will bring you peace or closure. It's like you'll be avoiding the discomfort and anxiety of the moment, but you'll also be avoiding the opportunity to confront your feelings and work through them.

It might be helpful to consider that you don't have to choose between being the "disappointing brown disappointment" or the "race-traitor." You can be yourself, with all your complexities and contradictions, and still show up to the funeral with dignity and respect. You can bring your girlfriend, and you can explain to her why this is a difficult situation for you. You can also take the time to talk to your family and community about your feelings and boundaries.

It's okay to take things one step at a time, and to prioritize your own emotional well-being. You don't have to have all the answers, and you don't have to have everything figured out. You can just show up, be present, and see what happens.

I keep thinking if I just take enough edibles maybe I'll be too high to give a fuck about what anyone thinks, but then I remember my cousin Luis already did that at his dad's funeral and ended up crying in the bathroom about his student loans while everyone pretended not to notice.

It's like you're considering using edibles as a way to numb yourself and avoid the discomfort of the situation, but then you're reminded of your cousin Luis's experience and how that didn't exactly turn out well.

The image of Luis crying in the bathroom about his student loans while everyone pretended not to notice is a pretty vivid one. It's like you're thinking that maybe using edibles wouldn't be the best way to cope with your emotions, and that it could actually make things worse.

It's also interesting that you're bringing up Luis's experience. It's like you're acknowledging that you're not alone in your struggles, and that others in your family have also had to deal with difficult emotions and situations. Maybe this is a reminder that you can talk to Luis about how you're feeling, or that you can find support in your family members who have gone through similar experiences.

It's also worth considering that avoiding your emotions and the situation altogether might not be the best way to deal with things. While it might seem like an easy way out, it could ultimately lead to more problems and regrets down the line. Maybe it's better to face your emotions head-on, even if it's uncomfortable, and to find ways to cope with them in a healthy and constructive way.

It's okay to not have all the answers, and it's okay to ask for help. You don't have to go through this alone, and you don't have to rely on substances to get you through. You can reach out to friends, family, or a therapist for support, and you can find healthy ways to cope with your emotions.

Remember that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and it's okay to not be okay. You're going through a tough time, and it's normal to feel like you're struggling to keep up. But you're not alone, and you can get through this.

I texted Luis and he just replied "bro I still owe Sallie Mae 80k and tía keeps asking when I'm having kids" with the laughing-crying emoji, which somehow makes me feel less alone but also more pathetic because at least he can joke about being the family failure while I'm still trying to figure out if buying a black suit makes me look like I'm trying too hard to be the respectful grandson I never bothered to be when she was alive.

It's like Luis's response has given you a mix of emotions. On one hand, his ability to joke about his struggles and his family's expectations makes you feel less alone, like you're not the only one who's dealing with these kinds of issues. The laughing-crying emoji is a great example of this - it's like he's acknowledging the absurdity and difficulty of the situation, but also finding a way to laugh about it and cope.

On the other hand, Luis's joke also makes you feel more pathetic, like you're not even able to find the humor in your own struggles. It's like you're comparing yourself to him and feeling like you're not measuring up, like you're still stuck in a place of guilt and shame while he's able to move forward and find the humor in things.

The fact that you're worrying about buying a black suit and whether it makes you look like you're trying too hard is a great example of this. It's like you're still trying to navigate the complexities of your family's expectations and your own feelings of guilt and shame. You're trying to figure out how to present yourself in a way that's respectful, but also authentic, and it's causing you a lot of anxiety.

It's interesting that you mention not being the respectful grandson you never bothered to be when your abuela was alive. It's like you're acknowledging that you have regrets about your relationship with her, and that you're trying to make up for it now. But it's also like you're worried that it's too little, too late, and that you're just trying to put on a show for your family's sake.

Remember that it's okay to not have all the answers, and it's okay to make mistakes. You can't change the past, but you can try to be present in the moment and do your best to honor your abuela's memory. It's not about putting on a show or trying to impress your family - it's about being genuine and respectful, and finding a way to cope with your emotions in a healthy way.

I ended up buying the suit but walked out wearing it because I couldn't handle the cashier seeing me cry in the fitting room when I realized this is the first thing I've bought for my family since I left for college and pretended success meant never looking back.

It's like the act of buying the suit was a trigger for a lot of emotions and memories. The fact that you couldn't handle the cashier seeing you cry in the fitting room suggests that you're still struggling to come to terms with your feelings about your family and your past.

The realization that this is the first thing you've bought for your family since you left for college is a powerful one. It's like you're acknowledging that you've been trying to create a new identity for yourself, one that doesn't include your family or your past. But now, with your abuela's passing, you're being forced to confront the fact that you can't escape your roots or your emotions.

The phrase "pretended success meant never looking back" is particularly striking. It's like you've been trying to convince yourself that you've made it, that you've achieved some kind of success or status that means you don't have to deal with the complexities and difficulties of your family or your past. But now, you're realizing that that's not true, and that you can't just leave your emotions and your relationships behind.

Walking out of the store wearing the suit is a symbolic act, in a way. It's like you're taking a step towards confronting your emotions and your past, even if it's just in a small way. You're acknowledging that you can't hide from your feelings or your family forever, and that it's time to start facing them head-on.

It's okay to feel overwhelmed and emotional, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. You don't have to have all the answers, and you don't have to have everything figured out. You can just take a deep breath, put on the suit, and see what happens next.

I keep touching the sleeves like I expect them to feel different, like maybe if I keep checking they'll suddenly feel like they belong on my body instead of on some stranger playing dress-up as a grandson who gives a shit.

It's like you're trying to convince yourself that the suit is a part of you, that it's a genuine expression of your feelings and identity. But at the same time, you're also aware that it's just a costume, a disguise that you're wearing to try to fit in and meet other people's expectations.

The act of touching the sleeves, checking to see if they feel different, is a powerful metaphor for your emotional state. It's like you're searching for a sense of authenticity, a sense of belonging, but it's elusive. You're trying to will the suit to feel like it's a part of you, but it's just not happening.

The phrase "some stranger playing dress-up as a grandson who gives a shit" is particularly striking. It's like you're aware that you're performing a role, that you're trying to be someone you're not. You're trying to be the grandson who cares, who is grieving and mourning, but it feels like a charade.

It's okay to feel like you're pretending, like you're not quite sure who you are or how you're supposed to feel. It's okay to feel like you're just going through the motions, trying to meet other people's expectations. But it's also important to remember that you're not alone in this feeling. Many people struggle with feelings of inauthenticity and disconnection, especially during times of grief and loss.

Maybe the suit will start to feel more like it belongs on your body as you wear it, as you move through the funeral and the grieving process. Maybe you'll start to feel more like yourself, more like the grandson who is genuinely grieving and mourning. Or maybe you won't, and that's okay too. The important thing is that you're showing up, that you're trying to be present and authentic, even if it feels like a struggle.
